This tool provides a cFE application runtime environment that can be used for integration and testing new applications.

See: Description

Packages 
Package Description
app  
ccsds  
curval  
fsw  
fswcore  
gui  
network  
util  
This tool provides a cFE application runtime environment that can be used for integration and testing new applications. The intention and role of this tool is to help developers develop and test applications and it is not intended to replace ground systems. It should be easy to configure and operate. It has been developed using freely available technology (Java, Eclipse's SWT/JFACE, and XML) and is intended to be maintained as an open source project within the CFS community. This overview is organized in the following sections:
  • cFE Configuration
  • CAppIT Configuration and Operations
  • XML Command and Telemetry Database
  • CAppIT Design

cFE Configuration

CAppIt makes assumptions about the cFE configuration. Currently some of these are hard coded in the Java source and others are encoded in the XML command and telemetry database. A future goal is to make these couplings explicit and easily managed by the user. In the future some aspects of CAppIT may be autonomously generated. Note the CFS uses the generic term message ID. In theory the cFE can be configured not to use CCSDS as its packet definition. However in practice the cFE has only been deployed using CCSDS packets. When using CCSDS a CFS message ID is the CCSDS Stream ID plus the command/telemetry definition bit.

TODO List

  • cFE must be compiled as a time client. CAppIT manages time
  • cFE startup must include CI, TO and SCH lab applications
  • The XML currently is designed to expect one command stream ID per application with function codes used for command
  • cFE Couplings: cFE msg IDs hardcoded in XML, def dir assumed (e.g. /cf vs /ram, tlm secondary header size (i.e. time) assumes 12 bytes

CAppIT Configuration and Operations

CAppIT is a development tool and is intended to be an open architecture. Many runtime configurations can be changed without digging into the CAppIT code. The CAppIT design document goes into detailed design and describes design guidelines for updating the Java code base. Since CAppIT is intended to be used by developers the debugging flag configurations are available to the user. The following directories and files are used to configure CAppIT:

/config
Contains the files that are used to change a user's configuration when CAppIT runs. All of these files use the Java XML property syntax
cappit-properties.xml
CAppIT application runtime configurations.
cappit-msg-ids.xml
Message identifiers used by the FSW and the /db/*.xml files. The keywords are also defined in CAPPIT.java
cappit-cfe-config.xml
cFE configuration parameters used by the FSW and the /db/*.xml files. The keywords are also defined in CAPPIT.java. A minimal set of cFE configuration paramters are defined to simplify maintenance. Soemday teh cFE configuration parameters may be defined in a database.
/db-core
Contains core command, table, telemetry, and file definitions. Core includes the cFE and any essential applications needed to provide a complete user application runtime environment. These definitions should only need to be changed if a new release of a cFE or core application is made that impacts the database. Depending on the scope of the cFE changes (e.g. configuration parameter changes) CAPPIT.java may also need to be modified.
/db-apps
Contains user application command, table, telemetry, and file definitions.
/src
log4j.properties
Contains logging configurations. Messages can be logged to a file and/or to the console. This is useful for troubleshotting and debugging.

TODO List

  • CAppIT manages time. Currently a disconnect between realtime and simulated time becuase actually task delays used and simulated tiem tick used. Note keep it simple when thsi is resolved. How this is resolved may depend on whether CAppIT is integrated with a simulator.

Application Integration

  • DB: Command, telemetry, table, file
  • Message IDs
  • Scheduler
  • Load and startup
  • The application's command, table, and telemetry user interface is defined in an XML file contained in the db-apps directory. The cappit-propoerties.xml file can be used to define a list of applications that can be loaded during CAppIT startup. New applications can be loaded whiel CAppIT is running. an application's database definitions can be refreshed without restarting CAppIT. A command does not exist for removing an application's database definition. If an application is removed teh user can either ignore the removed application's definitions or they can restart CAppIT.

XML Command and Telemetry Database

An application's command and telemetry packets are defined in an XML file located in the 'db' directory. Each XML should have a comment block at the top of the file describing any special notes. The following guidelines should be followed when creating XML definitions:

  • All keywords used in the XML files are defined as constants in JCAT.java
  • Commands: Add spaces to string parameters to make the command dialog box more readable

TODO List

  • cFE configuration dependencies are hard coded. See prologues in each XML file for details.
